title: Thursday, 4th July 2019
bodyHTML:
Blank canvas Good morning everyone
11:03 am

Right then. How do you think we'll get through the next hour?

I mean, there's this.

Excel Developer #Macro: Germany 10yr sovereign at -0.408 which is below ECB deposit rate of -0.4% thus German yield curve has inverted. Also in UK 10s at 0.666% which is below MPC policy rate of 0.75%, inverted too! So that on top of various YC inversions in USD we can expect a global recession in 12 months or so. Sell your equities into this current strength IMHO,

undefined

We can probably now rule out the possibility that they're sitting on an approach, so the theory becomes threefold:

At gunpoint I'd put probabilities on these theories of 40%, 10% and 50% respectively. So ... to summarise ....... dunno!

Spirax, as we said, is Goldman.

marktime Woking BC has bought its own centre and is building skyscrapers, incorporated as Thameswey
Spirax-Sarco Engineering PLC (SPX:LSE): Last: 9,170, down 230 (-2.45%), High: 9,405, Low: 9,065, Volume: 94.11k
11:19 am
BE11:19am

Spirax-Sarco trades at a greater than 110% premium to European Capital Goods on consensus 12m forward EV/EBIT (vs. c.20% 5Y median) and yet is near peak margins, faces a sequentially slowing growth outlook and has enjoyed some unrepeatable tailwinds. Following three years of sector-relative outperformance, we now see downside risks to consensus (5% below Visible Alpha 2020E EBIT). In our view, Spirax’s all-time-high relative-valuation multiple is at risk as growth expectations re-set. We downgrade to Sell from Neutral.

BE11:20am

We forecast a 4% organic sales CAGR over the next three
nyears (vs. 3% for sector and 6% for SPX over the past three): This is driven by decelerating industrial production globally, slower (albeit above-group) growth in Watson Marlow, and near-term drivers unwinding. In addition, we believe that Spirax’s ability to out-grow its markets could fade.
ROIC to converge with sector average: We forecast ROIC to
nfall to 15% in 2020 (110 bp lower than 2018). All divisions (ex. Chromalox) are around peak margins, and we see limited expansion given lower volumes, increased investments and disposals/exceptionals. We note ROCE is a reduced component of management compensation.

Excel Developer @mouselet: given the context of my remarks, definitely not corporate bonds because they are a risk asset, i.e. they perform badly in a recession (like defaulting)
BE11:21am

ROIC to converge with sector average: We forecast ROIC to
nfall to 15% in 2020 (110 bp lower than 2018). All divisions (ex. Chromalox) are around peak margins, and we see limited expansion given lower volumes, increased investments and disposals/exceptionals. We note ROCE is a reduced component of management compensation.

Upaswellasdown @Excel - indeed, even for sovereign debt, especially when the currency is not in the control of the government
Tom Dalgleish Thameswey is some sort of joint venturer?
Excel Developer Upaswellasdown: yes, exactly.
Tom Dalgleish reason I ask is that some super market owners here speculate that resi development is their saviour
11:22 am
undefined
marktime Surprisingly no, but partnered with McAlpine
BE11:23am

Keywords Studios, the videogame thingmy .....

GBKrona @BE - anything on Glencore please - goes from one disaster to another...
BE11:24am

.... outsourcer? Studio group? Not sure what to call it.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

Peel Hunt chooses to call it a sell.

BE11:25am

Mostly valuation.

Alphabeta Be nice to know whether anything of note on KWS from Peel as they were badly wrong with their £12.54 9/4 so is this just we think we're still right or anything material?
BE11:25am

We increase our EBITDA by 8% this morning on the back of
revisiting our estimates on operating leverage, but reflecting the
equity performance, we increase our target price and cut from
Hold to Sell. The share price has been on a roller coaster but it
appears to be ratchetting back up to its highs. This has seen its
next twelve months multiples expand by mid double digits, while
estimates have only ticked up slightly. It now sits 15% above the
first quartile despite growing slower at lower margins. Keywords
is a high quality business with its size allowing it to continue to
expand via M&A but the equity has gone up too far for the time
being. Because its growth and margin forecasts are below peers
and it does not appear to be seeing strong organic growth from its
M&A yet, we put it on median multiples. Hence, our new price
target of 1,310p (from 1254p) moves us from Hold to Sell.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

A few things concern us about KWS:
1. The potential for KWS to de-rate by double digits;
2. The cross sell performance to date despite many acquisitions;
3. The continuing M&A roll up story implied in the multiples;
4. The slowing organic growth due to the VMC acquisition; and
5. The soon to depart CFO, and uncertainties that come with change.

Excel Developer @Tom: I'd like that to be true. I'd like to think Tesco will release land to be built on. If that means they do the legwork and get planning permission with its massive bump up in valuation before passing it on to a housebuilder then fine. I support whatever it takes to solve UK housing crisis.
BE11:26am

(@Alphabeta: nah, doubt we'll cover that.)

Pharma @BE if you need filler, is there any grey on Christine Lagarde's nomination for the ECB job?

"Its revenue growth is being generated by acquisitions, whilst underneath that its organic growth has been reducing," says Peel Hunt. "In 2016
it was 24% and in 2018 it was 10% (15% excluding VMC). This is clearly a
question of the law of large numbers, but one concern is whether the company has been acquiring businesses that are dilutive for the financials and whether it may start to overpay for those that aren’t. "

BE11:28am

(First person to be pedantic about the law of large numbers gets a red card.)

11:29 am

Keywords announced the departure of David Broderick as CFO after three years; an excellent track record of M&A (€170m for 25 deals); financials (160% increase in revenues and 150% increase in EPS); and shareholder value (4x increase in share price). Whilst the CFO designate Jon Hauck has a great deal of experience in change management and M&A integration (Rentokil made 47 acquisitions in 2018 during his tenure), the sector is different and brings with it its own nuances.

BE11:36am

Add stuff about the market overall is as you'd expect. Canaccord can summarise:

11:35 am
BE11:36am

Good progress being made on improving customer satisfaction as sales releases are delayed.
Build rate remains robust with new home inventories increased by +19% at end of June.
Customer satisfaction rating improved in first seven months of new HBF period.
First half saw completions down by c.-6% to 7,584 from 8,072 with the ASP up by +1.2% to £216.9k. Revenue was down by -4.5% at £1.754n.
Reassuring news on operating margins which are expected to be around 30.8% in the first half, matching the full year 2018 number.
Site numbers were down by c.-8% in first half as sales releases were delayed. Sales rates per site held up at 0.74 (2018: 0.78).
Forward sales remain healthy at £1.622bn.
Full year volumes are expected to reflect the continued focus on customer care initiatives but it has +19% more built stock and market conditions will therefore be key for the full year outcome.
The Group continued to selectively invest in land with £239m (2018: £343m) spent.
Cash returns remain on track.

Excel Developer @Pharma: well she also has repeatedly reiterated that member states with fiscal headroom should do more, (looking at you Germany)
BE11:36am

Volumes are lower for the first six months, but for good reasons and market conditions continue to hold up well. Although there is a clear focus on improving customer care, it is very positive that margins for the first half will be at the full year 2018 level. The balance sheet remains in good shape and the Group is on track with its cash returns. The key debating point today is likely to be what the volume outcome for the full year will be. Clearly, the Group has more stock as it goes into the second half but it is signalling that volumes will continue to be impacted by the focus on customer care initiatives and will also depend on the autumn selling season trading conditions. We would not be surprised to see volumes edged down a bit for the full year with PBT consensus likely to come under a bit of pressure (-2-3%) but with good margins holding up and a decent autumn selling season, the profit outcome for the full year should still be good and close to current consensus. Shares have lagged and offer a very attractive dividend yield which looks secure, and management is making the right moves on the customer focus front with good financial metrics and operational performance continuing. We reiterate our BUY rating.

1966AndAllThat @Excel why would anyone want Euro to fail? No currency in an advanced society is a humanitarian disaster. A nukeless nuke

Hang on, Persimmon's on 2x 2019 NAV?

11:37 am

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Sales rates remain strong
As expected, the forward order book is down -3.45% yoy compared to -3.6% yoy on May 1. The weekly private sales rate per site continued to be strong at 0.74 (H118 0.78) operating from an average of c.345 (2018: 375) outlets during the period. Management expects begin work on an additional 85 developments during the second half. The Capital Return plan is progressing as expected with £350m paid to shareholders as a dividend on 2 July.
Strong dividend yield underpins BUY
After a strong run earlier in the year, the stock has come off recently and is now looking undervalued. On our preferred metric of EV/IC / ROCE, Persimmon is trading on 5.3x versus a peer median of 6.2x. Combining this with the highest dividend yield of our coverage (12% versus 8% median) and a strong balance sheet underpins our BUY recommendation on the stock.

Pharma It's entertaining that most of the candidates for the top EU jobs have reputational clouds hanging over them that would have ended political careers in UK (a plagiarised thesis, conviction for insider trading and criminal investigation into political payoffs)

BE11:41am

The shares have struggled during 2019 as a result of the problems the group has had with build quality/customer service and the LTIP issues. To date they are up 2% while the sector is up 12% and its two big peers, Barratt (+25%) and TW (+18%) have materially outperformed. In valuation terms the shares are trading on a P/NAV of 1.95x for CY19 with a sector leading 28.8% post tax RoE. The 12% dividend yield is c1.25x covered by earnings.

That's 11x EV/EBITA for mid-cycle EBITA of cE80m and 9x the trailing 12m EBITDA of E424m, so reasonable rather than knockout.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Who is interested in a company like Persimmon? Conduit for crony capitalism.

BE11:51am

But the process has been running since February that we know about, and probably before.

BE11:51am

Morgan Stanley:

11:51 am
BE11:51am

How does the offer compare to historical share prices? The price per share is a premium of about 10% vs the price of the stock when the first rumour emerged in Nov 2018 and is about a 2% premium vs the stock price before Osram confirmed talks with the private equity funds. We note that Osram shares since the spin-off from Siemens 6 years ago have traded in a range between the low €20's to almost €80. We currently have a €29 fair value on the name based on operational estimates for 2020e. What is the implied valuation? At €35 per share, Osram would be valued at almost 11x EV/EBITDA 2019e and 9x 2020e (MSe). Currently, Auto Suppliers stocks are valued at about 5x 2020e and relevant semi stocks for Osram at about 9x 2020e

GBKrona @marktime - indeed - or their ilk - M&G, Aviva Investors etc - everyone hungry for yield...
marktime A founder of CARLEX fighting exploitation by ripoff retirement housing development was Norman Greed, sadly no longer in residence
BE11:52am

And Kepler.

BE11:52am

Regarding the price offered, one could argue that Osram is currently seeing
depressed earnings, with the OS division likely to generate an adjusted
EBITDA margin of 16-17% this year compared with margins in the mid-to-high
20% range in recent years. However, we believe the offer is fair, considering
the time value of money and the low visibility on the potential timing of a
meaningful recovery in demand and earnings. For example, the latest
forecasts from our autos team call for 1.6% growth in light vehicle volumes in
2020E (following a drop of 3.8% in 2019E), implying flat demand vs. 2016. As
the offer matches our TP, we leave our rating and target price unchanged. Our
TP was derived from a combination of DCF and SOP valuations. Based on our
forecasts, our DCF (forecasts until 2023E, WACC of 8.5%, terminal growth
rate of 2%) and SOP (based on 2020E) models point to a fair value in the mid-
EUR20s, while we derive valuations based on management’s (more ambitious)
medium-term targets in the low-to-mid EUR40s. These medium-term targets
were set in September and November 2018, i.e. before the company
significantly lowered its guidance for 2019 in late March (comparable sales
growth guidance was cut from 0-3% growth to a 11-14% decline and the
adjusted EBITDA margin guidance was lowered from 12-14% to 8-10%, while
FCF guidance was cut from a positive amount in the mid-double-digit million
range to minus EUR50-150m). While our forecasts through to 2023E suggest
that management’s medium-term margin targets may have become too
ambitious, especially for the OS division, these targets may have been the
starting point for the group’s discussions with the private equity firms, and
hence we did consider them when setting our target price.

marktime Right, spin cycle nearly done, holding for IAG payout looking like a good call. Yammas folks
Blank canvas Midday already. Thanks for Persimmon BE. Good day all
BE12:00pm

Reuters and the Israeli local press had already identified Energean as leading the auction, albeit at a rather higher price of about $1.5bn.

BE12:01pm

Spangel says the actual price is very good at $2.6/boe and $11,000 per boe on a daily flowing basis

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

RBC can summarise terms so I don't have to.

BE12:02pm

Energean has agreed to acquire Edison E&P for $750m, plus a contingent payment of $100m payable following first gas (in ~2022) from Cassiopea, offshore Italy; and, potentially, an 8% royalty on any Profit Oil received from two key prospects offshore Egypt.
Portfolio: Edison E&P’s portfolio includes 2P reserves of 292mmboe in Egypt (52%), Italy (29%), Algeria (8%), UK and Norway (10%) and Croatia (1%). The acquisition price equates to $2.91 per 2P boe.
Approvals: Shareholders owning ~54% of the company's shares (pre-placing) have given irrevocable undertakings to vote in favour of the acquisition. Completion of the acquisition is subject to a longstop date of 10 months.
Payment: In addition to the proceeds from today's $265m placing, management intends to fund the initial $750m payment (and $115m of working capital requirements) with a new $600m Bridge Loan. However, given the time to deal completion, management expects to secure longer term (RBL or corporate) debt, and potentially some disposal proceeds.
Rationalisation: Management has been quick to announce plans to sell- on Edison's assets in the UK and Norway.
Rationale: The acquisition increases Energean's scale - in 2018 Edison produced 69kboe/d and generated revenues of $620m, well ahead of Energean's 4kboe/d and $90m, respectively. In 2021 the enlarged business is predicted to produce

140kboe/d, which in our universe puts it third behind Johan Sverdrup-fueled AKER BP and Lundin, and like the Norway-focused duo, management has an eye for a dividend (in the medium term).

Outlier: Edison is gas-weighted - gas accounts for 75-80% of reserves and production, and it is sold under fixed price contracts; consequently (enlarged) Energean's correlation to gyrating oil prices remains limited.
Newsflow: Development-led Energean now expects to participate in a series of new exploration wells, including two high-impact wells - North Thekah (7.5Tcf) and North East Hap'y (10Tcf) in Q4/19-Q1/20, as well as additional new field developments.

Ongoing: Although the acquisition of Edison appears transformational for Energean, it is still management's intention to utilise the full capacity of its newbuild FPSO, offshore Israel.
Risks: Portions of the deal await government approval; Edison's Iranian operation is excluded from the deal; some operations in Italy face environmental hurdles; decommissioning obligations are expected to be material, specifically in Italy and the UK.
